paragraphs.text:
%md
# About
**Objective:** Become familiar with building Convolutional Neural Networks with Keras
**File locations:** https://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvmtools/datasets/multiclass/
**Successful outcome:** You will have successfully trained several convolutional networks
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Deep Learning, Convolutional Neural Networks

---

About

Before you begin:

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setup
---

paragraphs.title: Retrieve the MNIST dataset from the internet if you have not already
paragraphs.text:
%sh
rm -f mnist*
wget https://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvmtools/datasets/multiclass/mnist.bz2
wget https://www.csie.ntu.edu.tw/~cjlin/libsvmtools/datasets/multiclass/mnist.t.bz2
bunzip2 mnist.bz2
bunzip2 mnist.t.bz2
ls mnist*

paragraphs.title: Import libraries
paragraphs.text:
%python
from keras.models import Sequential
from keras.utils import to_categorical
import datetime
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
import tensorflow as tf
import sklearn.datasets
from keras.layers import Dense, Dropout, Activation, Flatten, Conv2D, MaxPooling2D

%md
# Lab
---

paragraphs.title: Reshape the data
paragraphs.text:
%md
## Load, reshape and normalize the data
First, we want to explicity shape our data into a 2-D configuration. We'll end up with a 4-D tensor where the first dimension is the training examples, then each example is 28x28 pixels, and we'll explicitly say it's 1-layer deep. (Why? with color images, we typically process over 3 or 4 channels in this last dimension)

~~~
train_libsvm = "mnist"
test_libsvm = "mnist.t"

X_train, y_train = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(train_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_train = X_train.toarray()
X_train = X_train.reshape( (X_train.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_train = X_train.astype('float32')
X_train /= 255
y_train = to_categorical(y_train, num_classes=10)
print('X_train shape:',X_train.shape)
print('y_train shape:',y_train.shape)

X_test, y_test = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(test_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_test = X_test.toarray()
X_test = X_test.reshape( (X_test.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_test = X_test.astype('float32')
X_test /= 255
y_test = to_categorical(y_test, num_classes=10)
print('X_test  shape:',X_test.shape)
print('y_test  shape:',y_test.shape)
~~~

msg.data:
Load, reshape and normalize the data

First, we want to explicity shape our data into a 2-D configuration. We'll end up with a 4-D tensor where the first dimension is the training examples, then each example is 28x28 pixels, and we'll explicitly say it's 1-layer deep. (Why? with color images, we typically process over 3 or 4 channels in this last dimension)

train_libsvm = "mnist"
test_libsvm = "mnist.t"

X_train, y_train = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(train_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_train = X_train.toarray()
X_train = X_train.reshape( (X_train.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_train = X_train.astype('float32')
X_train /= 255
y_train = to_categorical(y_train, num_classes=10)
print('X_train shape:',X_train.shape)
print('y_train shape:',y_train.shape)

X_test, y_test = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(test_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_test = X_test.toarray()
X_test = X_test.reshape( (X_test.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_test = X_test.astype('float32')
X_test /= 255
y_test = to_categorical(y_test, num_classes=10)
print('X_test  shape:',X_test.shape)
print('y_test  shape:',y_test.shape)

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load, reshape and normalize the data

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Build the model

~~~
model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(8, # number of kernels 
				(4, 4), # kernel size
                padding='valid', # no padding; output will be smaller than input
                input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu')) # alternative syntax for applying activation

model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
~~~

msg.data:
Build the model

model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(8, # number of kernels 
                (4, 4), # kernel size
                padding='valid', # no padding; output will be smaller than input
                input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu')) # alternative syntax for applying activation

model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])

paragraphs.title: 2 - Build the model

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Train and test the model

~~~
start = datetime.datetime.today()

history = model.fit(X_train, y_train, batch_size=128, epochs=8, verbose=2, validation_split=0.1)

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=1)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
	print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))
~~~

msg.data:
Train and test the model

start = datetime.datetime.today()

history = model.fit(X_train, y_train, batch_size=128, epochs=8, verbose=2, validation_split=0.1)

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=1)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
    print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))

paragraphs.title: 3 - Train and test the model

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Plot the loss on the validation and train datasets

~~~
plt.plot(history.history['loss'])
plt.plot(history.history['val_loss'])
plt.title('model loss')
plt.ylabel('loss')
plt.xlabel('epoch')
plt.legend(['train', 'val'], loc='upper left')
~~~

Plot the loss on the validation and train datasets

plt.ylabel('loss')
plt.xlabel('epoch')
plt.legend(['train', 'val'], loc='upper left')

paragraphs.title: 4 - Plot the loss on the validation and train datasets

paragraphs.text:
%md
In our first convolutional MNIST experiment, we get to almost 99% validation accuracy in just a few epochs (a minute or so on CPU)!

The training accuracy is effectively 100%, though, so we've almost completely overfit (i.e., memorized the training data) by this point and need to do a little work if we want to keep learning.

msg.data:
In our first convolutional MNIST experiment, we get to almost 99% validation accuracy in just a few epochs (a minute or so on CPU)!

The training accuracy is effectively 100%, though, so we've almost completely overfit (i.e., memorized the training data) by this point and need to do a little work if we want to keep learning.

paragraphs.text:
%md
## Add a second convolution layer

~~~
model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(8, # number of kernels 
						(4, 4), # kernel size
                        padding='valid',
                        input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Conv2D(8, (4, 4)))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])

history = model.fit(X_train, y_train, batch_size=128, epochs=15, verbose=2, validation_split=0.1)

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=1)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
	print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))
~~~

Let's add a second convolution layer and more epochs to see if we can keep learning.

    print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))

paragraphs.title: 5 - Add a second convolution layer
6 - Plot the loss on the validation and train datasets

paragraphs.text:
%md
Our model is still overfitting!

%md
## Add dropouts and reduce kernels sizes

We're making progress on our test error -- about 99% -- but just a bit for all the additional time, due to the network overfitting the data.

There are a variety of techniques we can take to counter this -- forms of regularization. 

Let's try a relatively simple solution solution that works surprisingly well: add a pair of Dropout filters, a layer that randomly omits a fraction of neurons from each training batch (thus exposing each neuron to only part of the training data).

We'll add more convolution kernels but shrink them to 3x3 as well.

~~~
model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(32, # number of kernels 
						(3, 3), # kernel size
                        padding='valid',
                        input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Conv2D(32, (3, 3)))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Dropout(0.25))
model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Dropout(0.5))
model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
history = model.fit(X_train, y_train, batch_size=128, epochs=15, verbose=2, validation_split=0.1)

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=2)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
	print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))
~~~

msg.data:
Add dropouts and reduce kernels sizes

We're making progress on our test error – about 99% – but just a bit for all the additional time, due to the network overfitting the data.

There are a variety of techniques we can take to counter this – forms of regularization.

Let's try a relatively simple solution solution that works surprisingly well: add a pair of Dropout filters, a layer that randomly omits a fraction of neurons from each training batch (thus exposing each neuron to only part of the training data).

We'll add more convolution kernels but shrink them to 3x3 as well.

model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(32, # number of kernels 
                        (3, 3), # kernel size
                        padding='valid',
                        input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Conv2D(32, (3, 3)))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Dropout(0.25))
model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(Dropout(0.5))
model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])
history = model.fit(X_train, y_train, batch_size=128, epochs=15, verbose=2, validation_split=0.1)

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=2)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
    print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))

paragraphs.title: 7 - Add dropouts and reduce kernels sizes
8 - Plot the loss on the validation and train datasets
Lab wrapup
paragraphs.text:
%md
# Result
**You have now:** You have now successfully trained several convolutional networks.

From the last one, you should have a test accuracy of over 99.1%

For one more activity, try changing the optimizer to old-school "sgd" -- just to see how far we've come with these modern gradient descent techniques in the last few years.

Accuracy will end up noticeably worse ... about 96-97% test accuracy. 

Two key takeaways:

* Without a good optimizer, even a very powerful network design may not achieve results
* In fact, we could replace the word "optimizer" there with
    * initialization
    * activation
    * regularization
    * (etc.)
* All of these elements we've been working with operate together in a complex way to determine final performance

---

msg.data:
Result

You have now: You have now successfully trained several convolutional networks.

From the last one, you should have a test accuracy of over 99.1%

For one more activity, try changing the optimizer to old-school “sgd” – just to see how far we've come with these modern gradient descent techniques in the last few years.

Accuracy will end up noticeably worse … about 96-97% test accuracy.

Two key takeaways:

  • Without a good optimizer, even a very powerful network design may not achieve results
  • In fact, we could replace the word “optimizer” there with
    • initialization
    • activation
    • regularization
    • (etc.)
  • All of these elements we've been working with operate together in a complex way to determine final performance

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Solution
---

paragraphs.title: 1 - Load, reshape and normalize the data
paragraphs.text:
%python

train_libsvm = "/home/zeppelin/mnist"
test_libsvm = "/home/zeppelin/mnist.t"

X_train, y_train = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(train_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_train = X_train.toarray()
X_train = X_train.reshape( (X_train.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_train = X_train.astype('float32')
X_train /= 255
y_train = to_categorical(y_train, num_classes=10)
print('X_train shape:',X_train.shape)
print('y_train shape:',y_train.shape)

X_test, y_test = sklearn.datasets.load_svmlight_file(test_libsvm, n_features=784)
X_test = X_test.toarray()
X_test = X_test.reshape( (X_test.shape[0], 28, 28, 1) )
X_test = X_test.astype('float32')
X_test /= 255
y_test = to_categorical(y_test, num_classes=10)
print('X_test  shape:',X_test.shape)
print('y_test  shape:',y_test.shape)

X_train shape: (60000, 28, 28, 1)
y_train shape: (60000, 10)
X_test  shape: (10000, 28, 28, 1)
y_test  shape: (10000, 10)

paragraphs.title: 2 - Build the model
paragraphs.text:
%python

model = Sequential()

model.add(Conv2D(8, # number of kernels 
				(4, 4), # kernel size
                padding='valid', # no padding; output will be smaller than input
                input_shape=(28, 28, 1)))

model.add(Activation('relu'))

model.add(MaxPooling2D(pool_size=(2,2)))

model.add(Flatten())
model.add(Dense(128))
model.add(Activation('relu')) # alternative syntax for applying activation

model.add(Dense(10))
model.add(Activation('softmax'))

model.compile(loss='categorical_crossentropy', optimizer='adam', metrics=['accuracy'])

scores = model.evaluate(X_test, y_test, verbose=1)

print
for i in range(len(model.metrics_names)):
	print("%s: %f" % (model.metrics_names[i], scores[i]))

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Tutorials](http://hortonworks.com/tutorials/#tuts-developers) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Hortonworks Community Connection (HCC)](https://community.hortonworks.com/spaces/85/data-science.html?type=question) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Hortonworks Apache Spark Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/spark-overview/content/analyzing_data_with_apache_spark.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Hortonworks Apache Zeppelin Docs](https://docs.hortonworks.com/HDPDocuments/HDP3/HDP-3.0.1/zeppelin-overview/content/overview.html) - official Zeppelin documentation.

paragraphs.text: %angular
%angular
